paragraph: For example, there is concern about the concepts ­themselves—that explaining their distinctive features might raise the same hard problem that arises in the first instance for the ­experiences they pick out (Chalmers 2007). Further, Chalmers argues that, even if type-B materialism is correct, the explanation of consciousness will be quite distinctive: “our explanation will always require ­explanatorily primitive principles to bridge the gap from the physical to the ­phenomenal” (2010, p. 118).
